C167F6FFFD954C858C0F7357C85A2C2A.description: Energy released during nuclear reactions is much greater than the energy released during chemical reactions.

01CDB3AE61AB4A3CAD4E1C8662DB9558.description: Energy released in a nuclear reaction (fission or fusion) comes from the fractional amount of mass that is converted into energy. Nuclear changes convert matter into energy.

6E87FDBEA99B4884B634FB1F75562D84.description: A change in the nucleus of an atom that converts it from one element to another is called transmutation. This can occur naturally or can be induced by the bombardment of the nucleus with high-energy particles.

98544F22523A408B9A3B70C3D0185DC0.description: Performance Indicator:  Compare energy relationships within an atom's nucleus to those outside the nucleus.

862B74D698B043FFA506E9D48B075378.description: Physical properties of substances can be explained in terms of chemical bonds and intermolecular forces. These properties include conductivity, malleability, solubility, hardness, melting point, and boiling point.

8063D90F1641462BA74A30C5B67EB3E6.description: Intermolecular forces created by the unequal distribution of charge result in varying degrees of attraction between molecules. Hydrogen bonding is an example of a strong intermolecular force.

457CD8C9F0FA45F98932CD65BF57B710.description: Molecular polarity can be determined by the shape of the molecule and distribution of charge. Symmetrical (nonpolar) molecules include CO2, CH4, and diatomic elements. Asymmetrical (polar) molecules include HCl, NH3, and H2O.

9F9D35249E374A38B808A213D83240CB.description: The electronegativity difference between two bonded atoms is used to assess the degree of polarity in the bond.

117FA205AAC045C8A7ED128BEDBBFCE4.description: Electronegativity indicates how strongly an atom of an element attracts electrons in a chemical bond. Electronegativity values are assigned according to arbitrary scales.

5746D291BB3E4A46A112AA9C2C3D8EE0.description: When a bond is broken, energy is absorbed. When a bond is formed, energy is released.

589878D1F47849F984321E1DDF0798FB.description: Metals tend to react with nonmetals to form ionic compounds. Nonmetals tend to react with other nonmetals to form molecular (covalent) compounds. Ionic compounds containing polyatomic ions have both ionic and covalent bonding.

CA0C8A51C51C41D584A47C4EDE9512DC.description: Two major categories of compounds are ionic and molecular (covalent) compounds.

52B254D79CA44BAB93A837252631CB36.description: Some elements exist in two or more forms in the same phase. These forms differ in their molecular or crystal structure, and hence in their properties.

7DB9759A24CD426FA6CC9AD28EA9D0B8.description: In a multiple covalent bond, more than one pair of electrons are shared between two atoms. Unsaturated organic compounds contain at least one double or triple bond.

BC07BBD9495B42CE8E85224F7CC05F85.description: Electron-dot diagrams (Lewis structures) can represent the valence electron arrangement in elements, compounds, and ions.

7719AF85F187474FB66049D6D522501F.description: When an atom gains one or more electrons, it becomes a negative ion and its radius increases. When an atom loses one or more electrons, it becomes a positive ion and its radius decreases.

B8BC01E05A5F41C29F26CEADC162EC37.description: Atoms attain a stable valence electron configuration by bonding with other atoms. Noble gases have stable valence configurations and tend not to bond.

F60995EA367F41CC8492D7CC26BAA906.description:
Chemical bonds are formed when valence electrons are: 
• transferred from one atom to another (ionic) 
• shared between atoms (covalent) 
• mobile within a metal (metallic)

96AAF44CA87C4EDBA2016F7244DD10C2.description: Performance Indicator:  Explain chemical bonding in terms of the behavior of electrons.

4AD2F6F3BB674F3D933210358F8EBE3D.description: Energy and matter interact through forces that result in changes in motion

FC96CBDFA40D47D9B02D5336A2AA6845.description: There are benefits and risks associated with fission and fusion reactions

C6A7DC23AFB549CAAB53FBEF60CDACF7.description: There are inherent risks associated with radioactivity and the use of radioactive isotopes. Risks can include biological exposure, long-term storage and disposal, and nuclear accidents.

8E7CC0ED651F4DC7B0F69E8BE53FB468.description: Radioactive isotopes have many beneficial uses. Radioactive isotopes are used in medicine and industrial chemistry for radioactive dating, tracing chemical and biological processes, industrial measurement, nuclear power, and detection and treatment of diseases.

845AA7E428AB4C0EB7E6D0945BD769D5.description: Nuclear reactions can be represented by equations that include symbols which represent atomic nuclei (with mass number and atomic number), subatomic particles (with mass number and charge), and/or emissions such as gamma radiation.

21574A27E65C495FBCAB4D8B434A4803.description: Nuclear reactions include natural and artificial transmutation, fission, and fusion.

0C4698FF67F6488E8227C17D91F901F6.description: Each radioactive isotope has a specific mode and rate of decay (half-life).

90B9FCB74F4E430194F7680F60C3090F.description: Performance Indicator:  Explain the benefits and risks of radioactivity.

EA56715FDDAF41EDACA2EFD6C0DB23F6.description: The concepts of kinetic and potential energy can be used to explain physical processes that include: fusion (melting), solidification (freezing), vaporization (boiling, evaporation), condensation, sublimation, and deposition.

A167D65C9B3542948867A6A785E02696.description: Temperature is a measurement of the average kinetic energy of the particles in a sample of material. Temperature is not a form of energy.

BE2BF37F7621437593325DA3AB4C2BC0.description: Heat is a transfer of energy (usually thermal energy) from a body of higher temperature to a body of lower temperature. Thermal energy is the energy associated with the random motion of atoms and molecules.

A83D986D090340E2B9718673579CFA85.description: Performance Indicator:  Explain heat in terms of kinetic molecular theory.

F348105F681F456F8F8A4D639E70C4D7.description: Energy released or absorbed during a chemical reaction (heat of reaction) is equal to the difference between the potential energy of the products and potential energy of the reactants.

EA423933BB6F49CEB2293575C95E8F13.description: Energy released or absorbed during a chemical reaction can be represented by a potential energy diagram.

A21E02BEE1124C6B915F2E801FCD63C5.description: Chemical and physical changes can be exothermic or endothermic.

14434F98841A4C40BB45EF94E8F2786A.description: Energy can exist in different forms, such as chemical, electrical, electromagnetic, thermal, mechanical, nuclear.

354E372D656749958B642E2A56A7ECDC.description: Performance Indicator:  Observe and describe transmission of various forms of energy.

CA7B805C05C24DD5A1A9E8D0BBAA746E.description: Energy exists in many forms, and when these forms change energy is conserved.

ADEEB9643D4A48F6A849E5D0C9DF1EA4.description: LeChatelier's principle can be used to predict the effect of stress (change in pressure, volume, concentration, and temperature) on a system at equilibrium.

D5304639D41540E9804F2167D0A78196.description: At equilibrium the rate of the forward reaction equals the rate of the reverse reaction. The measurable quantities of reactants and products remain constant at equilibrium.

314B49A5CE7F423BA875357B4024067F.description: Some chemical and physical changes can reach equilibrium.

28BAE033DAFC49CFACBE63E3EE6899FF.description: A catalyst provides an alternate reaction pathway, which has a lower activation energy than an uncatalyzed reaction.

2D36E36C63F04FFBAA67E6B3D477F775.description: The rate of a chemical reaction depends on several factors: temperature, concentration, nature of the reactants, surface area, and the presence of a catalyst.

81D8009017A044F5901335EE5F60321C.description: Equal volumes of gases at the same temperature and pressure contain an equal number of particles.

74823B393BD849C389297CBA6BADF43E.description: Collision theory states that a reaction is most likely to occur if reactant particles collide with the proper energy and orientation.

009B4D078FDA4676966C76FA50305303.description: Kinetic molecular theory describes the relationships of pressure, volume, temperature, velocity, and frequency and force of collisions among gas molecules.

38006C7C93F04907AA5C593E2F0F6B22.description:
Kinetic molecular theory (KMT) for an ideal gas states that all gas particles: 
• are in random, constant, straight-line motion. 
• are separated by great distances relative to their size; the volume of the gas particles is considered negligible. 
• have no attractive forces between them. 
• have collisions that may result in a transfer of energy between gas particles, but the total energy of the system remains constant.

6C4370C233E94A3BB37BAAB6370A4E09.description: The concept of an ideal gas is a model to explain the behavior of gases. A real gas is most like an ideal gas when the real gas is at low pressure and high temperature.

4177F1C401C64E9EAE09129210485FDB.description: Performance Indicator:  Use kinetic molecular theory (KMT) to explain rates of reactions and the relationships among temperature, pressure, and volume of a substance.

8875A7EB5A0743F9B7E61E49B46089E3.description: The percent composition by mass of each element in a compound can be calculated mathematically

D9BB4F84C7854F8D9638187BFDE05C9B.description: The formula mass of a substance is the sum of the atomic masses of its atoms. The molar mass (gram-formula mass) of a substance equals one mole of that substance.

E5C1C2E9D7D445A38FA995B1B7732139.description: The empirical formula of a compound is the simplest whole-number ratio of atoms of the elements in a compound. It may be different from the molecular formula, which is the actual ratio of atoms in a molecule of that compound.

2E4805C9E3DA4BE4929F07369B28BF5F.description: A balanced chemical equation represents conservation of atoms. The coefficients in a balanced chemical equation can be used to determine mole ratios in the reaction.

8BF8FBFAE57F41A0A1D1DA84AE9EEADD.description: In a redox reaction the number of electrons lost is equal to the number of electrons gained.

46928F029F984B62BA5BEEBE62954E39.description: In all chemical reactions there is a conservation of mass, energy, and charge.

079DAE99A79640E393130782C7D77E07.description: Performance Indicator:  Apply the principle of conservation of mass to chemical reactions.

7C2B26B810E1488D976839CC6420697D.description: An electrolytic cell requires electrical energy to produce a chemical change. This process is known as electrolysis.

F0E3343DFF8D40A2AB2E5648BD6F97C5.description: A voltaic cell spontaneously converts chemical energy to electrical energy.

4E06DAA565EB4715BB5F23BCBC12E46E.description: An electrochemical cell can be either voltaic or electrolytic. In an electrochemical cell, oxidation occurs at the anode and reduction at the cathode.

1CBF333C188F44E2A69CA77FCEF029C2.description: Oxidation numbers (states) can be assigned to atoms and ions. Changes in oxidation numbers indicate that oxidation and reduction have occurred.

E84F230FDBC44233A61AE61862D704A5.description: A half-reaction can be written to represent oxidation.

EF9727BF31354D138EB6EDBF7FF81C4B.description: Oxidation is the loss of electrons.

242C248174644485BA8C7F03B476685F.description: A half-reaction can be written to represent reduction.

AA7659BC83B7474EAB37D3DBA86C443C.description: Reduction is the gain of electrons.

A7AE2F687AF84CA48FECB148D10234CF.description: An oxidation-reduction (redox) reaction involves the transfer of electrons (e-).

B936BFF36AF4441698FE879EF75B190E.description: Types of organic reactions include addition, substitution, polymerization, esterification, fermentation, saponification, and combustion.

9DCAEA30C6A24C288195DDF3BB3D1442.description: Types of chemical reactions include synthesis, decomposition, single replacement, and double replacement.

A74557D5CAF343AFA4C5DBDD49A56766.description: A physical change results in the rearrangement of existing particles in a substance. A chemical change results in the formation of different substances with changed properties.

11620A165A50445EBCCC0824EFB18BC5.description: Performance Indicator:  Use atomic and molecular models to explain common chemical reactions.

DC770E4D032942F898C50E32BABC3F9A.description: Titration is a laboratory process in which a volume of a solution of known concentration is used to determine the concentration of another solution.

B370DE8BD2404BE2B5F5F416CDBB11D3.description: There are alternate acid-base theories. One theory states that an acid is an H+ donor and a base is an H+ acceptor.

B0B2A2086EB54008AAAEA01252C431C3.description: In the process of neutralization, an Arrhenius acid and an Arrhenius base react to form a salt and water.

EA0F71F6EB9540CD9DB62C93B670877D.description: Arrhenius bases yield OH-(aq), hydroxide ion as the only negative ion in an aqueous solution.

4C1DB5D42AFC4515801DEB40FFC1002D.description: Arrhenius acids yield H+(aq), hydrogen ion as the only positive ion in an aqueous solution. The hydrogen ion may also be written as H3O+(aq), hydronium ion.

042A9D02A3A84B2A8EF2527A5EBBD106.description: Behavior of many acids and bases can be explained by the Arrhenius theory. Arrhenius acids and bases are electrolytes.

227FBC590DB248358C9F607B5C60F151.description: On the pH scale, each decrease of one unit of pH represents a tenfold increase in hydronium ion concentration.

68EF982D6BDC402CAF1E4BC25E9C5D0A.description: The acidity or alkalinity of an aqueous solution can be measured by its pH value. The relative level of acidity or alkalinity of these solutions can be shown by using indicators.

8B854470C12F49F7BE7160EF9E87435F.description: An electrolyte is a substance which, when dissolved in water, forms a solution capable of conducting an electric current. The ability of a solution to conduct an electric current depends on the concentration of ions.

2FA6CCFBF5F0471BBB02883520A2FA37.description: The addition of a nonvolatile solute to a solvent causes the boiling point of the solvent to increase and the freezing point of the solvent to decrease. The greater the concentration of solute particles, the greater the effect.

F933C9B12FCE4C5E981E71E4A7808328.description: The concentration of a solution may be expressed in molarity (M), percent by volume, percent by mass, or parts per million (ppm).

223D7FBBBA52417C86B023C9E00F6921.description: A solution is a homogeneous mixture of a solute dissolved in a solvent. The solubility of a solute in a given amount of solvent is dependent on the temperature, the pressure, and the chemical natures of the solute and solvent.

EFA756642A7F45E0B526C0F23912440C.description: Differences in properties such as density, particle size, molecular polarity, boiling and freezing points, and solubility permit physical separation of the components of the mixture.

F15DA3E5BE564866ACA87DE4BA39EF77.description: Systems in nature tend to undergo changes toward lower energy and higher entropy.

969ABBDE09D448FAA45E964320A34253.description: Entropy is a measure of the randomness or disorder of a system. A system with greater disorder has greater entropy.

44CD414E0F964D75B16FFD8C7FCE11E3.description: The three phases of matter (solids, liquids, and gases) have different properties.

3721FF371FEE46DAB32DFB617EDAD5F7.description: The structure and arrangement of particles and their interactions determine the physical state of a substance at a given temperature and pressure.

C13A7DBF68DA43AB8C35F881E04B9CD7.description: Isomers of organic compounds have the same molecular formula, but different structures and properties.

0393B190517046A5A7F4C2ED5A53FB62.description: Organic acids, alcohols, esters, aldehydes, ketones, ethers, halides, amines, amides, and amino acids are categories of organic compounds that differ in their structures. Functional groups impart distinctive physical and chemical properties to organic compounds.

EC7E5CE900524E7A99E97726020EF432.description: Hydrocarbons are compounds that contain only carbon and hydrogen. Saturated hydrocarbons contain only single carbon-carbon bonds. Unsaturated hydrocarbons contain at least one multiple carbon-carbon bond.

137E05D78EC34BC99C5C21090C109829.description: Organic compounds contain carbon atoms, which bond to one another in chains, rings, and networks to form a variety of structures. Organic compounds can be named using the IUPAC system.

44236083AC0A41DBB13472225E186435.description: Types of chemical formulas include empirical, molecular, and structural.

9D63DE8F2EB04A9B8F5B40BB892C6020.description: Compounds can be differentiated by their physical and chemical properties.

55D466F3085D45818F205C7AA2CA21DF.description: A compound is a substance composed of two or more different elements that are chemically combined in a fixed proportion. A chemical compound can be broken down by chemical means. A chemical compound can be represented by a specific chemical formula and assigned a name based on the IUPAC system.

ED9FFE993D244CCABC8745110D4C4581.description: The succession of elements across the same period demonstrates characteristic trends: differences in atomic radius, ionic radius, electronegativity, first ionization energy, metallic/nonmetallic properties.

E7537A7B0A934F71AE1E0A0510AE7405.description: The succession of elements within the same group demonstrates characteristic trends: differences in atomic radius, ionic radius, electronegativity, first ionization energy, metallic/nonmetallic properties.

0BD326271CCB4D7988857B6C5BB74660.description: For Groups 1, 2, and 13-18 on the Periodic Table, elements within the same group have the same number of valence electrons (helium is an exception) and therefore similar chemical properties.

678A5167C4144FC2B7125E6B868EFC0B.description: The placement or location of an element on the Periodic Table gives an indication of the physical and chemical properties of that element. The elements on the Periodic Table are arranged in order of increasing atomic number.

0B845C67A2B342C9AE17EB3BF3155438.description: Elements can also be differentiated by chemical properties. Chemical properties describe how an element behaves during a chemical reaction.

546D3E87DE974024BA67753DF5806B70.description: Elements can be differentiated by physical properties. Physical properties of substances, such as density, conductivity, malleability, solubility, and hardness, differ among elements.

28F93E0075284F338AF443D86C03DE4C.description: Elements can be classified by their properties and located on the Periodic Table as metals, nonmetals, metalloids (B, Si, Ge, As, Sb, Te), and noble gases.

64E1502F99E3444CA5E8FC6E50D66FAD.description: Elements are substances that are composed of atoms that have the same atomic number. Elements cannot be broken down by chemical change.

A89B3B8E98BE4D80A604378D1A7F11DB.description: The proportions of components in a mixture can be varied. Each component in a mixture retains its original properties.

9034FAAFDFDC40199D256A257D059016.description: Mixtures are composed of two or more different substances that can be separated by physical means. When different substances are mixed together, a homogeneous or heterogeneous mixture is formed.

37915B7727A1486FA95AC6D879B4D467.description: A pure substance (element or compound) has a constant composition and constant properties throughout a given sample, and from sample to sample.

A472D95AF5C34173A8700C35F2EEFC32.description: Matter is classified as a pure substance or as a mixture of substances.

615C5F770100427E86C4B308F6FAB8D1.description: Spontaneous decay can involve the release of alpha particles, beta particles, positrons, and/or gamma radiation from the nucleus of an unstable isotope. These emissions differ in mass, charge, ionizing power, and penetrating power.

B57CBB6429FF4B7BA9FED035C0DE7321.description: Stability of an isotope is based on the ratio of neutrons and protons in its nucleus. Although most nuclei are stable, some are unstable and spontaneously decay, emitting radiation.

88815CE178194F258A3B727BB8FF5141.description: The average atomic mass of an element is the weighted average of the masses of its naturally occurring isotopes.

4BDF593507544F7995E41F64C3DAC3A0.description: Atoms of an element that contain the same number of protons but a different number of neutrons are called isotopes of that element.

A925D676F40B4C9F933C79F4C974CC4D.description: The outermost electrons in an atom are called the valence electrons. In general, the number of valence electrons affects the chemical properties of an element.

0BFC709693B14955B813012E64E0FF21.description: When an electron returns from a higher energy state to a lower energy state, a specific amount of energy is emitted. This emitted energy can be used to identify an element.

D84AB366C2334C188A8489C00C34BD37.description: When an electron in an atom gains a specific amount of energy, the electron is at a higher energy state (excited state).

DB373970B89D4203BA4FDCC582C67A2D.description: Each electron in an atom has its own distinct amount of energy.

2BE1FA882AC5484DBEFDFF0CA62DEB64.description: In the wave-mechanical model (electron cloud model) the electrons are in orbitals, which are defined as the regions of the most probable electron location (ground state).

4CBF7F987C63426D85F930C6EB79D666.description: The number of protons in an atom (atomic number) identifies the element. The sum of the protons and neutrons in an atom (mass number) identifies an isotope. Common notations that represent isotopes include: 14C, 14C, carbon-14, C-14. 6

62C16BE253DB4FC4A112BC96427BB862.description: The mass of each proton and each neutron is approximately equal to one atomic mass unit. An electron is much less massive than a proton or a neutron.

6B89E55043AE427FBF765D9EE4A0019D.description: Protons and electrons have equal but opposite charges. The number of protons equals the number of electrons in an atom.

24331FE3D886454FB1EB822E696DC19D.description: The proton is positively charged, and the neutron has no charge. The electron is negatively charged.

F71D6FA522C34E849939478D1438DF42.description: Subatomic particles contained in the nucleus include protons and neutrons.

A6E8AEBF83234804B8C3CC54C0F4D138.description: Each atom has a nucleus, with an overall positive charge, surrounded by negatively charged electrons.

4FBCEA5F1DF1456F9E9F299851AB59B6.description: The modern model of the atom has evolved over a long period of time through the work of many scientists.

7365DC06F3AC4A23A5D82FCC7C27D59F.description: Performance Indicator:  Explain the properties of materials in terms of the arrangement and properties of the atoms that compose them.

FAA27AB2C9BE4518A0ACE04CFF1E0C4F.description: Matter is made up of particles whose properties determine the observable characteristics of matter and its reactivity

785475A02073450286678B08273186AE.description: distinguish between nonpolar covalent bonds (two of the same nonmetals) and polar covalent bonds 5.2k

C90ED51C232245BEB2B834DC43F4BD0A.description: determine the noble gas configuration an atom will achieve by bonding 5.2b

9A94D414421F4E13A6451F0CF81CA6B4.description: explain vapor pressure, evaporation rate, and phase changes in terms of intermolecular forces 5.2m

3E5B136B14B54442ACB8CDFEB1E46F9C.description: compare the physical properties of substances based on chemical bonds and intermolecular forces, e.g., conductivity, malleability, solubility, hardness, melting point, and boiling point 5.2n

E5A55F1828DE41B6BCFBE24EAD9737E3.description:
demonstrate bonding concepts, using Lewis dot structures representing valence electrons: 5.2a, 5.2d
§ transferred (ionic bonding) 
§ shared (covalent bonding) 
§ in a stable octet Example: atom ion K. K+ .. .. - :Cl: :Cl: . ..

01DACD48B02D4677AA38BBE300C35A1D.description: Students will explain chemical bonding in terms of the behavior of electrons.

A199B1B5F7D0429FB8FB384A984E0860.description: Energy and matter interact through forces that result in changes in motion.

04722665C43D440EB5D5EC72149A7CED.description: identify specific uses of some common radioisotopes, such as I-131 in diagnosing and treating thyroid disorders, C-14 to C-12 ratio in dating once-living organisms, U-238 to Pb-206 ratio in dating geological formations, and Co-60 in treating cancer 4.4d

3EA1A520FF144D608C67B1AC444499B4.description: complete nuclear equations; predict missing particles from nuclear equations 4.4c

5169FB4858D7473C800EB634FA6BE87A.description: compare and contrast fission and fusion reactions 4.4a, 4.4f, 5.3b

31E64E97467C4D9390DA76872AEB66A1.description: calculate the initial amount, the fraction remaining, or the halflife of a radioactive isotope, given two of the three variables 4.4a

333A7C18F3C74D85BFD39229E19F71ED.description: Explain the benefits and risks of radioactivity.

43EA1942A3184D44814FE5AD4F053D69.description: calculate the heat involved in a phase or temperature change for a given sample of matter 4.2c

44B8D0C6075A45659144D83382FCBE72.description: qualitatively interpret heating and cooling curves in terms of changes in kinetic and potential energy, heat of vaporization, heat of fusion, and phase changes 4.2a, 4.2c

E5F6B11C899E40C9B7A1A46A3D83F0E1.description: explain phase change in terms of the changes in energy and intermolecular distances 4.2b

0575C8A0540D4FC7B7F9ED375349B40C.description: distinguish between heat energy and temperature in terms of molecular motion and amount of matter 4.2a, 4.2b

F48B57ACFC32441C8FF802B8296595A4.description: Explain heat in terms of kinetic molecular theory.

E28D32BCDBB348A69C4496F4B1635A4A.description: read and interpret potential energy diagrams: PE reactants, PE products, activation energy (with or without a catalyst), heat of reaction 4.1c, 4.1d

E5564E76B4A5472B9867CEF0117574D8.description: distinguish between endothermic and exothermic reactions, using energy terms in a reaction equation, ∆H, potential energy diagrams, or experimental data 4.1b

5E5D96F17B7644D69EFD8E8923F41E2A.description: Observe and describe transmission of various forms of energy.

8273AF61E9BF43D7B907895223A71B28.description: Energy exists in many forms, and when these forms change, energy is conserved.

811901FE476A43998295CB4245AE835F.description: identify examples of physical equilibria as solution equilibrium and phase equilibrium, including the concept that a saturated solution is at equilibrium3.4h

2D248A4866A74E11BE1D5975DC3C28C7.description: use collision theory to explain how various factors, such as temperature, surface area, and concentration, influence the rate of reaction 3.4d

DABD9FB997AE4A5587F75D795BA45BAB.description: qualitatively describe the effect of stress on equilibrium, using LeChatelier’s principle 3.4j

57B45ED761F4494683319E6496883A83.description: describe the concentration of particles and rates of opposing reactions in an equilibrium system 3.4i

721DAF418F9F401583F2D2E57C670B32.description: convert temperatures in Celsius degrees (oC) to kelvins (K), and kelvins to Celsius degrees 3.4e

F852821223C140B3A816F7555B0365AB.description: solve problems, using the combined gas laws 3.4c

34577C35B08B4505A17CBDFB95E29BDA.description: explain the gas laws in terms of KMT 3.4c

23AAC46C6DC0445BAE9C048BEA8FFBEC.description: Use kinetic molecular theory (KMT) to explain rates of reactions and the relationships among temperature, pressure, and volume of a substance.

BA62A7B0043D41C0957EA76248C3C542.description: determine the number of moles of a substance, given its mass 3.3f

62579EED8F214181B2644D91309AA5A0.description: calculate the formula mass and gram-formula mass 3.3f

109B9D7DF9144D169A01A5FCFF532BB3.description: determine the molecular formula, given the empirical formula and the molecular mass 3.3d

A23B133B151147AF81F382CF4B5F40E6.description: determine the mass of a given number of moles of a substance 3.3f

77932AA139E04D00905ACD5D8CA3415C.description: determine the empirical formula from a molecular formula 3.3d

E9B77A376A89484EB86473947CE8EA50.description: calculate simple mole-mole stoichiometry problems, given a balanced equation 3.3c

E3033969D29848EA93D062DC3F787EBE.description: create and use models of particles to demonstrate balanced equations 3.3a, 3.3c

8B6209DEB4C54CE9AA8EFD750079DC20.description: interpret balanced chemical equations in terms of conservation of matter and energy 3.3a, 3.3c

29429790C77F4685B17D7BFBED7FB4D5.description: balance equations, given the formulas for reactants and products 3.3c

BFFE4DE2F7674D8B8324B8F2E1AF55C1.description: Apply the principle of conservation of mass to chemical reactions.

C95273C4A95F49EF847B69349AEA167D.description: use an activity series to determine whether a redox reaction is spontaneous 3.2k

AE64B2DDD7A64606BA9632E3A7EA544D.description: compare and contrast voltaic and electrolytic cells 3.2j

80D8C2911E1244E7AFC81124BFAF1A65.description: identify and label the parts of an electrolytic cell (cathode, anode) and direction of electron flow, given the reaction equation 3.2l

7C113EF234FD4D50B0249B388566B6CA.description: identify and label the parts of a voltaic cell (cathode, anode, salt bridge) and direction of electron flow, given the reaction equation 3.2k

DE52B13830E144FDAE8B70AF258FDA47.description: write and balance half-reactions for oxidation and reduction of free elements and their monatomic ions 3.2f, 3.2h

CA473A979F304E0CB6895F3013F74FC6.description: balance equations, given the formulas of reactants and products 3.2a, 3.3a, 3.3c

6242F9437A8E4265BC350FD83B00700C.description: determine a missing reactant or product in a balanced equation 3.2c, 3.2d

0D9A44425A9D4534908001FF132ECAE6.description: distinguish between chemical and physical changes 3.2a

5FF1E5C117994C129742E0774B9670C7.description: Use atomic and molecular models to explain common chemical reactions.

F574A7E5B438496E8EC3AC317A4F3B7E.description: use particle models/diagrams to differentiate among elements, compounds, and mixtures 3.1r

DC6157CFD1504305ADECB534CBAA3D25.description: calculate the concentration or volume of a solution, using titration data 3.1zz

53B410C2593143DFBAB30D14A03E2A69.description: write simple neutralization reactions when given the reactants 3.1xx

C5912CFAF4A7469A8E75E7B2BC5BB333.description: interpret changes in acid-base indicator color 3.1ss

8E631783513642B5A20F2CE0D68DCE8C.description: identify solutions as acid, base, or neutral based upon the pH 3.1ss

99797B06C8234C6EA0715095CFAEBC26.description: given properties, identify substances as Arrhenius acids or Arrhenius bases 3.1uu

4E440E2DD6644D348EE23B98DFEAE999.description: describe the preparation of a solution, given the molarity 3.1pp

B5CDAB54A7764444890E636B20495649.description: calculate solution concentration in molarity (M), percent mass, and parts per million (ppm) 3.1pp

43DD45458CB74FD7BC85003126CD3C49.description: use solubility curves to distinguish among saturated, supersaturated, and unsaturated solutions 3.1oo

C5C9B28055AF4626AE2B3CBE462D7B30.description: apply the adage “like dissolves like” to real-world situations 3.1oo

76414BF6A380415D8897B05298096BC1.description: describe the processes and uses of filtration, distillation, and chromatography in the separation of a mixture 3.1nn

323F0813209B479A86C3BEB9B70315EE.description: compare the entropy of phases of matter 3.1mm

73789DAD9F7C40C3A9D1039A1D202D35.description: use a simple particle model to differentiate among properties of solids, liquids, and gases 3.1jj, 3.1kk

8B35BE5F7D714739B9FAB9BEA50B6799.description: draw structural formulas for alkanes, alkenes, and alkynes containing a maximum of ten carbon atoms 3.1ff, 3.1gg

997285E25E4E44E7B3454903203E079F.description: draw a structural formula with the functional group(s) on a straight chain hydrocarbon backbone, when given the IUPAC name for the compound, 3.1ff, 3.1hh

6833182005E94E9D8C8038925EC87E4F.description: distinguish among ionic, molecular, and metallic substances, given their properties 3.1dd, 3.1w, 5.2g, 5.2h

18AA8CF653874D70BE90CA3084A4D951.description: describe the states of the elements at STP, 3.1jj

898CC5B6933B4F95926EFAF87D9BAB80.description: classify an organic compound based on its structural or condensed structural formula O (i.e., CH3COOH or -C-C-OH) 3.1ff, 3..1gg, 3.1hh

ACCCBB05373A4F9D8444856A7B46904E.description: explain the placement of an unknown element on the Periodic Table based on its properties 3.1v, 3.1w, 3.1x, 3.1y

A081CD6D4D504A6CB488A116207F06DD.description: determine the group of an element, given the chemical formula of a compound, e.g., XCl or XCl2 3.1z

7CBD222DD5B440B180666A5142566128.description: compare and contrast properties of elements within a group or a period for Groups 1, 2, 13-18 on the Periodic Table 3.1aa, 3.1bb

0C4CA6A9D1F640879EF62C030892418A.description: classify elements as metals, nonmetals, metalloids, or noble gases by their properties 3.1v, 3.1w, 3.1x, 3.1y

42C4C1AF66C14A788B2126531C5F8F3F.description: calculate the atomic mass of an element, given the masses and ratios of naturally occurring isotopes 3.1n

550A21CF995D483B95798CCDE9E2A7AA.description: given an atomic mass, determine the most abundant isotope 3.1h

63D0407AA6354F08A3D614E91ED7F2A0.description: determine decay mode and write nuclear equations showing alpha and beta decay 3.1p, 4.4b

64A595DFA857420EB4D1DFA0C63FE11D.description: draw a Lewis electron-dot structure of an atom 3.1l

F731E1E9577E4A0C9EDD44945227B850.description: distinguish between valence and non-valence electrons, given an electron configuration, e.g., 2-8-2 3.1l

6E803C2581D640919BD31EF65359EF1C.description: identify an element by comparing its bright-line spectrum to given spectra 3.1k

4EC07E5F7BFF48A5AD65F5D353AEEA3E.description: distinguish between ground state and excited state electron configurations, e.g., 2-8-2 vs. 2-7-3 3.1j

186D3E71BF6F4FCBA1827917527D0364.description: calculate the mass of an atom, the number of neutrons or the number of protons, given the other two values 3.1f

AB6D29857A7740A5A7DE62D824A089F3.description: determine the number of protons or electrons in an atom or ion when given one of these values 3.1e

7315E953C8C94B06A14FF0B85C760B19.description: relate experimental evidence (given in the introduction of Key Idea 3) to models of the atom 3.1a

D4173ECFC7674202908E00721A7FACFC.description: use models to describe the structure of an atom 3.1b, 3.1c

3676E59644294C86936F2BA6928A6C4D.description: Explain the properties of materials in terms of the arrangement and properties of the atoms that compose them.

D797B6CEF8A64EAF9F51427E272EBE7C.description: Matter is made up of particles whose properties determine the observable characteristics of matter and its reactivity.

CF11D72A6A1A4F48867F7B85DCBCC710.description:
Solving interdisciplinary problems involves a variety of skills and strategies, including
effective work habits; gathering and processing information; generating and analyzing
ideas; realizing ideas; making connections among the common themes of mathematics,
science, and technology; and presenting results.
If students are asked to do a project, then the project would require students to:
• work effectively
• gather and process information
• generate and analyze ideas
• observe common themes
• realize ideas
• present results

A5F2DC5CE1564E12A9BB30E4D304A431.description:
Explain and evaluate phenomena mathematically and scientifically by formulating
a testable hypothesis, demonstrating the logical connections between the scientific
concepts guiding the hypothesis and the design of an experiment, applying and
inquiring into the mathematical ideas relating to investigation of phenomena, and
using (and if needed, designing) technological tools and procedures to assist in the
investigation and in the communication of results.
• design an experiment that requires the use of a mathematical concept to solve a
scientific problem, e.g., an experiment to compare the density of different types
of soda pop

027464DAB0E44D5AA00DABB2A11763A0.description:
Design solutions to real-world problems on a community, national, or global scale,
using a technological design process that integrates scientific investigation and rigorous
mathematical analysis of the problem and of the solution.
• design a potential solution to a regional problem, e.g., suggest a plan to adjust
the acidity of a lake in the Adirondacks

763135DBD42747D19BB190974A399FB9.description:
Analyze and quantify consumer product data, understand environmental and economic
impacts, develop a method for judging the value and efficacy of competing
products, and discuss cost-benefit and risk-benefit trade-offs made in arriving at
the optimal choice.
• compare and analyze specific consumer products, e.g., antacids, vitamin C

19B1F0570A114E7E8101551D060376FB.description:
Analyze science/technology/society problems and issues on a community,
national, or global scale and plan and carry out a remedial course of action.
• carry out a remedial course of action by communicating the plan to others, e.g.,
writing and sending “a letter to the editor”

98B7CA9426FE4A36A605BBEFF40B6C33.description:
The knowledge and skills of mathematics, science, and technology are used together to
make informed decisions and solve problems, especially those relating to issues of science/technology/society,
consumer decision making, design, and inquiry into
phenomena.

8F6309455BA04138BC2DAC0951C28E3F.description:
Identifying patterns of change is necessary for making predictions about future
behavior and conditions.
Examples include:
• use graphs to make predictions, e.g., half-life, solubility
• use graphs to identify patterns and interpret experimental data, e.g., heating
and cooling curves

DD09BC7960914CC7B0A5455C716199BA.description:
Cite specific examples of how dynamic equilibrium is achieved by equality of
change in opposing directions.
• explain how a system returns to equilibrium in response to a stress, e.g.,
LeChatelier’s principle

F0F5285894E24FD9AFB9724457FEBCD0.description:
Describe specific instances of how disturbances might affect a system’s equilibrium,
from small disturbances that do not upset the equilibrium to larger disturbances
(threshold level) that cause the system to become unstable.
• explain how a small change might not affect a system, e.g., activation energy

45629E85F4434BCE83563CB41052A312.description:
Equilibrium is a state of stability due either to a lack of change (static equilibrium) or a
balance between opposing forces (dynamic equilibrium).

94F9D56C7F244118A1F49F1DDF14073B.description:
Extend the use of powers of ten notation to understanding the exponential
function and performing operations with exponential factors.
• use powers often to represent a large range of values for a physical quantity,
e.g., pH scale

CA69582EA0234F2F8DD8F263AD1B1A2B.description:
Describe the effects of changes in scale on the functioning of physical, biological, or
designed information systems.
• show how microscale processes can resemble or differ from real-world
processes, e.g., microscale chemistry

8956FCF28DC54C7AA58721031DE20480.description:
The grouping of magnitudes of size, time, frequency, and pressures or other units of
measurement into a series of relative order provides a useful way to deal with the
immense range and the changes in scale that affect the behavior and design of systems

7818A64D8E1444F68C5C947E848C581F.description:
Compare predictions to actual observations, using test models.
• compare experimental results to a predicted value, e.g., percent error

B5464A8D075A4D0C8204D5E45B46EC94.description:
Find and use mathematical models that behave in the same manner as the
processes under investigation.
• show how mathematical models (equations) describe a process, e.g., combined
gas law

56EBEA26BF694DF698546A227F395C09.description:
Collect information about the behavior of a system and use modeling tools to
represent the operation of the system.
• show how information about a system is used to create a model, e.g., kinetic
molecular theory (KMT)

201DFE1CF171451B875C803B6509A898.description:
Revise a model to create a more complete or improved representation of the system.
• show how models are revised in response to experimental evidence, e.g., atomic
theory, Periodic Table

01361EC9542C47DBAB8CD61064156BFC.description:
Models are simplified representations of objects, structures, or systems used in analysis,
explanation, interpretation, or design

2E036B62A8384595B3BEF985600729D0.description:
Through systems thinking, people can recognize the commonalities that exist among all
systems and how parts of a system interrelate and combine to perform specific
functions.
Examples include:
• use the concept of systems and surroundings to describe heat flow in a chemical
or physical change, e.g., dissolving process

AAC74E435CBB49719D096251D69058E3.description:
Knowledge of the impacts and limitations of information systems is essential to its
effectiveness and ethical use.
Examples include:
• critically assess the value of information with or without benefit of scientific
backing and supporting data, and evaluate the effect such information could
have on public judgment or opinion, e.g., environmental issues
• discuss the use of the peer-review process in the scientific community and
explain its value in maintaining the integrity of scientific publication, e.g., “cold
fusion”

3A72A1584AB6411E89A4307C450D1A85.description:
Information technology is used to retrieve, process, and communicate information as a
tool to enhance learning.
Examples include:
• use the Internet as a source to retrieve information for classroom use, e.g.,
Periodic Table, acid rain

616C70FE4771440582A358BAF8553E23.description:
Engineering design is an iterative process involving modeling and optimization (finding
the best solution within given constraints); this process is used to develop technological
solutions to problems within given constraints.
If students are asked to do a design project, then:
• Initiate and carry out a thorough investigation of an unfamiliar situation and
identify needs and opportunities for technological invention or innovation.
• Identify, locate, and use a wide range of information resources, and document
through notes and sketches how findings relate to the problem.
• Generate creative solutions, break ideas into significant functional elements,
and explore possible refinements; predict possible outcomes, using mathematical
and functional modeling techniques; choose the optimal solution to the
problem, clearly documenting ideas against design criteria and constraints; and
explain how human understandings, economics, ergonomics, and environmental
considerations have influenced the solution.
• Develop work schedules and working plans which include optimal use and cost
of materials, processes, time, and expertise; construct a model of the solution,
incorporating developmental modifications while working to a high degree of
quality (craftsmanship). Devise a test of the solution according to the design criteria and perform the
test; record, portray, and logically evaluate performance test results through
quantitative, graphic, and verbal means. Use a variety of creative verbal and
graphic techniques effectively and persuasively to present conclusions, predict
impact and new problems, and suggest and pursue modifications.

82E9A6D28A3545F8931959CA3F31B78C.description:
Develop a written report for public scrutiny that describes the proposed explanation,
including a literature review, the research carried out, its results, and suggestions
for further research.

BAE126483F77419FACD8077A50ADC984.description:
Using results of the test and through public discussion, revise the explanation and
contemplate additional research.

CEFF016FC94D4415BE874275CFB84774.description:
Assess correspondence between the predicted result contained in the hypothesis
and the actual result, and reach a conclusion as to whether or not the explanation
on which the prediction is supported.
• evaluate experimental methodology for inherent sources of error and analyze
the possible effect on the result
• compare the experimental result to the expected result; calculate the percent
error as appropriate

75EBF30044A5440AB68D5B9FE0DC145E.description:
Apply statistical analysis techniques when appropriate to test if chance alone
explains the result

9A9FB5CC802548AF88BBC19DEF7F15BF.description:
Use various means of representing and organizing observations (e.g., diagrams,
tables, charts, graphs, equations, and matrices) and insightfully interpret the
organized data.
• organize observations in a data table, analyze the data for trends or patterns,
and interpret the trends or patterns, using scientific concepts

6F1C240B294148BC9BD9609C94AF22A5.description:
The observations made while testing proposed explanations, when analyzed using conventional
and invented methods, provide new insights into phenomena.

2BBF9F3DB2094E19998598DD79FB41CE.description:
Carry out a research plan for testing explanations, including selecting and developing
techniques, acquiring and building apparatus, and recording observations
as necessary.
• determine safety procedures to accompany a research plan

8521A527320D4762AB9CAA18545F3030.description:
Develop and present proposals including formal hypotheses to test explanations,
i.e.; they predict what should be observed under specific conditions if their explanation
is true.
• develop research proposals in the form of “if X is true and a particular test Y is
done, then prediction Z will occur”

9DA78C78563C4253937DE6F5946DD1A3.description:
Refine research ideas through library investigations, including information
retrieval and reviews of the literature, and through peer feedback obtained from
review and discussion.
• use library investigations, retrieved information, and literature reviews to
improve the experimental design of an experiment

62EDDC196D9A474A9D2CDF8D82F33804.description:
Devise ways of making observations to test proposed explanations.
• design and/or carry out experiments, using scientific methodology to test proposed
calculations

C184256A87564AC782B83F2DE1E3DDE1.description:
Beyond the use of reasoning and consensus, scientific inquiry involves the testing of proposed
explanations involving the use of conventional techniques and procedures and usually
requiring considerable ingenuity

EAC5149276494F5B8BF1A262F336A9C6.description:
Work towards reconciling competing explanations, clarifying points of agreement
and disagreement.
• evaluate the merits of various scientific theories and indicate why one theory
was accepted over another

2BA2BC98E8154F25A3D73735362E00F2.description:
Hone ideas through reasoning, library research, and discussion with others,
including experts.
• locate data from published sources to support/defend/explain patterns
observed in natural phenomena

1EF08B69C1A6455E9C7C6F4A0D3AAA6F.description:
Elaborate on basic scientific and personal explanations of natural phenomena, and
develop extended visual models and mathematical formulations to represent
thinking.
• use theories and/or models to represent and explain observations
• use theories and/or principles to make predictions about natural phenomena
• develop models to explain observations

9509F052B1EF414C80E59F07357451D5.description:
The central purpose of scientific inquiry is to develop explanations of natural phenomena
in a continuing, creative process.

02567A36E4B242CC88D0F8133138CF9C.description:
Apply algebraic and geometric concepts and skills to the solution of problems.
• state assumptions which apply to the use of a particular mathematical equation
and evaluate these assumptions to see if they have been met
• evaluate the appropriateness of an answer, based on given data

F32153A1ECB64B31B2D99C1371EBBB22.description: Critical thinking skills are used in the solution of mathematical problems.

C8AEA7A642904D4BAAADCF341A2CD15F.description:
Use deductive reasoning to construct and evaluate conjectures and arguments, recognizing
that patterns and relationships in mathematics assist them in arriving at
these conjectures and arguments.
• interpret a graph constructed from experimentally obtained data
◆ identify relationships
§ direct
§ inverse
◆ apply data showing trends to predict information

A10B43BC6BBF486CB2B91B6DBC9B7A61.description: Deductive and inductive reasoning are used to reach mathematical conclusions

19F396233CE84F94BD891C298651C87A.description:
Use algebraic and geometric representations to describe and compare data.
• organize, graph, and analyze data gathered from laboratory activities or other
sources
◆ identify independent and dependent variables
◆ create appropriate axes with labels and scale
◆ identify graph points clearly
• measure and record experimental data and use data in calculations
◆ choose appropriate measurement scales and use units in recording
◆ show mathematical work, stating formula and steps for solution
◆ estimate answers
◆ use appropriate equations and significant digits
◆ show uncertainty in measurement by the use of significant figures
◆ identify relationships within variables from data tables
◆ calculate percent error
• recognize and convert various scales of measurement
◆ temperature
§ Celsius (°C)
§ Kelvin (K)
◆ length
§ kilometers (km)
§ meters (m)
§ centimeters (cm)
§ millimeters (mm)
◆ mass
§ grams (g)
§ kilograms (kg)
◆ pressure
§ kilopascal (kPa)
§ atmosphere (atm)
• use knowledge of geometric arrangements to predict particle properties or
behavior

311E0937655D4025B52F44FCAC7BA707.description: Abstraction and symbolic representation are used to communicate mathematically.
